por.por_cntn:
Cybersecurity Workforce: Bridging the Gap

This project supported community college students in their academic pursuit of a Cybersecurity AAS degree through mentorship, collaboration, skill preparation, and other support activities. The goal of the project was on developing diverse, educated, and skilled cybersecurity professionals for local industry and government throughout Southern Maryland. It addressed the current cybersecurity workforce gap that exists throughout the Washington, DC region and is emblematic of the lack of qualified cybersecurity personnel that presently persists in the United States today.

Intellectual Merit: This project resulted in a new Information Assurance concentration within the Cybersecurity AAS program focused on business continuity and disaster recovery as well as cybersecurity risk management. Certification preparation workshops and a boot camp to support students with technical preparation were offered as well as guest speakers, field trips, hackathons, and other career enrichment activities. Cybersecurity awareness workshops were provided to promote program offerings and a virtual learning community was developed to provide mentorship and on-going student support. Open Labs with an emphasis on "Learn, Work, Play" were implemented at multiple campuses to provide cybersecurity students with professional experience as lab assistants.

Broader Impact: Emphasis throughout the project was placed on community building both at the college as well as in the larger cybersecurity community so students felt that they belonged and were connected to the workforce and industry. A project community survey was distributed to students as both a pre-test when they began the project in year one at the start of their cybersecurity coursework, and again as a post-test at the conclusion of year two when they finished their degree program. The survey questionnaire measured students' sense of connectedness and belonging to the project, the Cybersecurity program, and the college as a whole.

Comparing the pre- and post-surveys, the results showed that students felt a greater sense of community as they moved through the project and their academic coursework in the cybersecurity program. The study concluded that increased feelings of connectedness to the project activities through authentic shared learning experiences promoted belonging as well as provided social and academic supports to help students be successful in the cybersecurity program. These feelings of connectedness will carry forward into current and future workforce positions within the in-demand cybersecurity profession.

Culminating Outcome: Students connectedness with their peers, cybersecurity faculty, and the college, as well as a newfound sense of belonging within the cybersecurity community have provided additional enrichment for these new cybersecurity professionals to be successful in this technical field for the long term. By working collaboratively with industry partners to enhance the cybersecurity curriculum and through implementation of real-world cybersecurity activities for students to enhance their community college experience, this project increased student interest and satisfaction with the cybersecurity academic program, improved retention to support program completion, and resulted in new cybersecurity professionals joining this in-demand workforce as committed and dedicated employees.


Last Modified: 12/21/2023
Modified by: Mary Beth Klinger

This project supported community college students in their academic  pursuit of a Cybersecurity AAS degree through mentorship, collaboration,  skill preparation, and other support activities. The goal of  the project was on developing diverse, educated, and skilled  cybersecurity professionals for local industry and government  throughout Southern Maryland. It addressed the current cybersecurity  workforce gap that exists throughout the Washington, DC region and is  emblematic of the lack of qualified cybersecurity personnel that  presently persists in the United States today.


Intellectual Merit: This project resulted in a new  Information Assurance concentration within the Cybersecurity AAS program  focused on business continuity and disaster recovery as well as  cybersecurity risk management. Certification preparation workshops and a  boot camp to support students with technical preparation were offered  as well as guest speakers, field trips, hackathons, and other career  enrichment activities. Cybersecurity awareness workshops were provided  to promote program offerings and a virtual learning community was  developed to provide mentorship and on-going student support. Open Labs  with an emphasis on "Learn, Work, Play" were implemented at multiple  campuses to provide cybersecurity students with professional experience  as lab assistants.


Broader Impact: Emphasis throughout the project  was placed on community building both at the college as well as in the larger cybersecurity community so students felt that they belonged and  were connected to the workforce and industry. A project community  survey was distributed to students as both a pre-test when they began  the project in year one at the start of their cybersecurity coursework,  and again as a post-test at the conclusion of year two when they finished  their degree program. The survey questionnaire measured students' sense  of connectedness and belonging to the project, the Cybersecurity program, and the college as a whole.


Comparing the pre- and post-surveys, the results showed that students felt a  greater sense of community as they moved through the project and their  academic coursework in the cybersecurity program. The study concluded  that increased feelings of connectedness to the project activities  through authentic shared learning experiences promoted belonging as well  as provided social and academic supports to help students be successful  in the cybersecurity program. These feelings of connectedness will  carry forward into current and future workforce positions within the  in-demand cybersecurity profession.


Culminating Outcome: Students connectedness with  their peers, cybersecurity faculty, and the college, as well as a  newfound sense of belonging within the cybersecurity community have  provided additional enrichment for these new cybersecurity professionals  to be successful in this technical field for the long term. By working  collaboratively with industry partners to enhance the cybersecurity  curriculum and through implementation of real-world cybersecurity  activities for students to enhance their community college experience,  this project increased student interest and satisfaction with the  cybersecurity academic program, improved retention to support program  completion, and resulted in new cybersecurity professionals joining this  in-demand workforce as committed and dedicated employees.
